title.__text: My Rails Experience - Getting Started

content.__text:
In my previous entry I started talking about Rails.

In this entry I will get more technical (using windows 7).

Instant Rails




The quickest way to start with rails in windows is to download "instant-rails".


You will have to click the Ruby Forge link to get to downloads.
It will take a couple of minutes.
Unzip it, and find the 'exe' file to run.

Running 'Instant Rails' means you are running the server and a 'mysql' DB.

By default the ports used are 80 for Apache Server, you can easily modify this by clicking the "I" button >> configure >> Apache.
Look for "80" - there's more than one and replace.

Console


In order to open a console which is "rails aware" click the "I" button and select "Rails Application" >> "Open Ruby Console Window". run "ruby --version" in order to make sure ruby is active.

Getting mysql driver



By default rails will use sqlite database (even though instant-rails comes with myssql). I like to use "mysql". Ruby has a built-in adapter for mysql, but it is recommended you will download a better one like this : 
gem install mysql


And when I will create a new application I will need to specify to use "mysql" like this : 
rails --database=mysql  appName



Rails Version


Here are some helpful commands to help you organize your rails version

  • gem list --local rails
    - lists the rails versions you have installed

  • rails --version
    - to find out which rails version you are running

  • gem install rails --version X.Y.Z
    - to install a specific version of rails

  •  rails X.Y.Z command
    - for every rails command you can specify the version to use

  • gem update rails
    - to update the rails versions you have

  • rake rails:freeze:gems
    - this will copy the gems you are using into your application - making sure you application will run even if the environment does not have the required versions. 
  • rake rails:unfreeze
    - undoes the previous command

  • rake rails:freeze:edge
    - use the latest snapshot of rails




The version of rails you are using can be found in the file "environment.rb". Search for a line that looks like this : 
RAILS_GEM_VERSION = "2.2.2"



You can use the above commands in order to make documentation for rails like this : 

rails temp
cd temp
rake rails:freeze:gems
rake doc:rails


It will take a while.

Programming Command


This is probably the most important part since you will use these command often. 


  • rake db:create RAILS_ENV='development'
    - to create the DB for development. Replace 'development' with : 'production' and 'test' when needed.

  • rails --database=mysql appName
    - to create a new application with mysql

  • rake db:migrate
    - to perform DB changes

  • ruby script/generate scaffold name \
    field:type field2:type2
    - will create MVC files. - the possible types are : :binary, :boolean, :date, :datetime, :decimal,
    :float, :integer, :string, :text, :time, and :timestamp

  • ruby script/server
    - to run the server - you can specify a different port if needed




A small exercise



These are the most basic commands I can think of. With these you can create a small application that allows editing, reading and indexing - which is a lot.

Once you think you're done setting up the environment try creating a blog post application that allows creating new blog posts, listing them and editing existing.

The blog posts should have a title and a body.. that's it.. (Solutions in following posts).

title.__text: My Rails Experience - Teaser

content.__text:
Ruby is a programming language that appeared with Java at 1995, but made its big breakthrough thanks to Rails which is a framework that uses Ruby.


For those of you who know FUSE for PHP, some concepts will already be familiar.

While Ruby is yet another programming language, Rails is yet another framework for creating web applications. However ordinary, it has some tricks up its sleeves.

This blog is the first of many, in which I will summarize some key points to Ruby and Rails. In this entry I will talk about what you can expect from experiencing Rails. The following entry will start being more technical.



From Java to Ruby


So far, the only environment for web development that I've worked with is Java and Tomcat. As I dived into Rails, I was amazed to discover the amount of code I don't need to write.

In the book, they often write "magic" instead of explaining how it is done. The so called "magic" is a method definition called method_missing.
If you call a method on an Object, but that method wasn't defined, the call will reach "method_missing". So you can dynamically respond to methods that were not defined.

Database Development

Rails is the first framework I know that tries to handle the DB Schema problem.
The problem is there's no direct link between the source version and the Database.
If I check-out source from some old date, there's no "good way" to make sure the DB Schema matches that sources I have.

Rails however, creates a different file (SQL like) with a time-stamp, for each schema modification. These files have 2 operations - create and drop. These operations allow you to traverse back and forward on the DB state during development.

I really liked this approach as it seems to have a real insight on how it should be handled. If you maintain these files well - including manual modifications - you should be able to run these scripts on the deploy server for installing, uninstalling, upgrades and even downgrades. (I never heard of teams supporting downgrades).



Buying Rails Book


You probably thought that the first step would be - "learn Ruby". Well, that step is pretty optional. Once you started with Rails, your Ruby skills will catch on.
Plus, Ruby has quite an extensive documentation. So you will be just fine diving into Rails.

This is the first time I decided to "go by the book". I read the book "Agile Web Development with Rails" and I have to say - it's pretty good. I strongly recommend it.

Since I don't mind reading books from the screen, I bought just the eBook. You will also be fine with the hard-copy. Even though it has about 600 pages, there is an extensive index that helps you search the book.

There are also tutorials available online and I recommend searching for them after you read the book.

Testing


As a former Mercury employee, I was enthusiastic to discover the extensive support Rails have for testing. It allows you to handle sessions, and assert for redirects.
Tests are auto-generated as well, so the starting point for tackling tests is pretty good.


Quirks

There are some quirks along the way. For example - it surprised me to learn that the book directs me to download a product called "instant rails". Which is not found in the rails site.

This product comes with a database, an IDE, a server and a nice GUI in a ZIP file. No installation is required. You simply download "instant rails", run the exe file, and start writing. Other than defining the database driver (which is a simple command line), no other action is required in order to see actual results.


IDEs


The book has a chapter dedicate to IDEs. Basically it tells you - use Unix with Text-Mate.

Since I am a windows user, I had to make a research on the matter.
Jetbrains (IntelliJ creators) created an entire IDE just for Ruby and Rails called RubyMines. This IDE costs 100$. I evaluated it, and was impressed. This IDE was not mentioned in the book. IntelliJ has plugins to support Ruby and Rails, but for me, it is too heavy, whilte RubyMines seems to be thinner.

NetBeans - mentioned in the book - also has support for Rails. This includes nice Wizards to run Rails commands.

Surprisingly enough - instant rails comes with an IDE , which is not mentioned in the book. This IDE is called SCITE. Doesn't do much, but great for use while reading the book. Ruby reduces the amount of code you will write, so using SCITE is pretty sufficient.

Deploying

Deployment seems to be the hardest part. There's an entire chapter dedicated to it in the book, but it doesn't really help. Since I come from the Java world, using Tomcat, I read about the possibility to use "JRuby" which is an easy way to run Ruby from Java, and there's really not much needed in order to do this transition, however the results are pretty disappointing - it consumes a lot of memory, and really slows down the server. Tomcat usually loads fast, but with JRuby it suddenly takes more than a minute to load (on a fast computer).


Screen Casts


Once you feel good with your Rails skills you will want to check out the famous "blog in 15 mins with rails" screen-cast. They don't specify some initial stuff - such as getting the DB up and running, but since they cover this well in the book, you will be fine. After you did that, it really does take about 15 minutes to write the blog.

Other Documentation


Documentation for Ruby and Rails increases with every passing day.
It amazes me how many people believe in it.

As Java developer there are enough forums and blogs for every subject I need, and I was afraid this was not the case in RoR. There are plenty documentations and tutorials to help you get around. The Ruby library is being extended every day, so you can also expect to have "copy-paste" code for common problems.

Conlcusion


It is definitely cool. I strongly believe that Rails is here to stay, if not "on Ruby" than at least in spirit. It teaches a lot about organizing your project, writing good code, agility and most important - fun.

It is a language you can learn as a hobby AND see cool results. 3 months is more than enough to go over the entire book and say "I know RoR".

title.__text: My Quest for Rest

content.__text:
When I finally decided to tackle the REST approach, I first read about Restlet,Fuse,Spring and Jersey .

That was quite a headache :)
I finally decided to go on Jersey for several reasons :
  1. It is an implementation of a JSR.
  2. It had the shortest tutorials.

When I learn something new for the first time, It's important to me to have a good experience. So I search for a Plug & Play, with as little Plug as possible.

Spring requires a lot of background and its tutorials were TOO long. I couldn't find instructions to set up FUSE, and Restlet seemed too abstract.

While they all support annotations, Jersey seems to have the most straight forward approach. It involves 2 simple and expected steps which are : include a jar, and define a servlet.. and you're good to go. Even though the documentation it quite poor, it shouldn't take you long to get results. (After I decided to try Jersey, it took me 10 minutes - and that includes solving a jar version collision problem).

In this blog I will try to write a quick-reference to Jersey.



Plug Servlet Mapping - web.xml 


            
   Jersey REST Service            

   com.sun.jersey.spi.container.servlet.ServletContainer         
         
      com.sun.jersey.config.property.packages
              jersey            
            1


** Make sure to change the param-value according to your environment


        Jersey REST Service       
       /rest/*

** Make sure to select your own url-pattern

Plug Maven Dependency



          com.sun.jersey
          jersey-server
          1.1.4


** If you're using Hibernate, you will get an error with MethodMissing. 
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader.accept(Lorg/objectweb/asm/ ClassVisitor;I)V

You should specify another dependency in pom and verify that hibernate still operates fine. Hibernate uses asm 1.5 version and Jersey uses 3.0. 


    
   asm
   asm
   3.1


Play - Create a simple resource

create a class that looks like this : 
package jersey;
import javax.ws.rs.GET;
import javax.ws.rs.Path;
@Path("/users")
public class Users {   
 @GET    
  public String getUsers(){ return "users"; }

** The package name should match the one from web.xml.

Go to URL :
http://yourserver/rest/users and you should see "users" printed.
Congratulations - you wrote your first web-service.. now lets dig deeper into those annotations.

** Complex objects are by default referred to as XML. If you add @XmlRootElement everything will go smoothly and you can write things like : 
  @GET
    public Users getXml(){
        return this;    
}

Where this is the root element for a list of all users.

  @GET
    @Path("/{username}")
    public User getUser(@PathParam("username")String username){
        if (users.containsKey(username)){
            return users.get(username);
        }        return null;
    }

Where user is a root element by itself.
See here that we show the use of Path param. in "get" queries it is quite easy to have a param. We all know how to do that..

What about post , delete and put ? 
  @POST
    @Path("/{username}")
    public void addUser(@PathParam("username")String username){
        users.put(username, new User(username,0));
    }

    @PUT
    @Path("/{username}")
    public Response updateUser(@PathParam("username")String username){
        if (users.containsKey(username)){
            User user = users.get(username);
            user.setUpdated(user.getUpdated() +1);
        }
        else{
            users.put(username,new User(username,0));
        }
        return Response.ok().build();
    }

    @DELETE
    @Path("/{username}")
    public void deleteUser(@PathParam("username") String username){
        if (users.containsKey(username)){
            users.remove(username);
        }
    }

How do you build a query for this ?
** See that all the paths are the same, just the method changes.

Well, I use the XMLHttpRequest object like this : 
 var xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    xmlhttp.open(method,url,false);
    var text =  xmlhttp.responseText.replace(/    $('output').innerHTML =
                       "status : " + xmlhttp.status +
                      "
status Text : "  + xmlhttp.statusText+
                      "
response Text : " +  text;

** NOTE : the "url" should assume that same host is used. This means my URL for
exmple is : "/guy_mograbi/rest/users" - to list all users or "/guy_mograbi/rest/users/user1" - to get user1.

If you use the entire path ("http://....") - you will see an error like this : 
uncaught exception: [Exception... "Component returned failure code: 0x80004005 (NS_ERROR_FAILURE) [nsIXMLHttpRequest.send]" nsresult: "0x80004005 (NS_ERROR_FAILURE)" location: "JS frame :: http://mograbi.co.il/guy_mograbi/jsps/examples/jersey_webService.jsp :: execute :: line 39" data: no]

So beware. In a future blog I will explain how to create a cross-domain request. (which is important in order to publish your APIs).

The method variable gets the values : POST,DELETE,PUT as string and that creates the desired query.

Another method is using a form, but then you need to change the annotation
 @DELETE
 @Consumes(APPLICATION_FORM_URLENCODED)
     public void deleteUser(@FormParam("username") String username){
        if (users.containsKey(username)){
            users.remove(username);
        }
    }


I haven't tried that yet though :)


Receiving complex types

TBA

References

You can see a small example of this working at My Example Page

title.__text: Enums - Did You Know ?

content.__text:
Enumration

Enums


Here are some stuff you won't find so easily in your usual Enums tutorials


Inheritance


Enums cannot extend other classes since they already extend the Enum class.

However - they can implement an interface

Abstract methods


Enums can have abstract methods, and you will have to provide the implementation in enum decleration.

In this example I show an Enum for date formats with a "isSuitable" method that receives a string and returns true iff the string applies to the template.
(Normally you would probably use SimpleDateFormat). 

public enum DateFormats {

    SHORT{

        boolean isSuitable(String dateString) {
            return dateString.length() < 10;
        }},
    MEDIUM{

        boolean isSuitable(String dateString) {
            return dateString.length() > 10 && dateString.split(" ").length < 15;
        }},
    FULL{

        boolean isSuitable(String dateString) {
            if (dateString.contains("AM") || dateString.contains("PM")) return true;
            return dateString.length() > 10 && dateString.split(" ").length > 15;
        }};

    abstract boolean isSuitable(String dateString);
}

As you can see each format has a different logic to determine if the string suits it.
It won't be logical to use a single method with parameters.

However this method might be cumbersome with big enums since it requires the definition of the method for enum definition. In the code above I would like to add a null and empty check to all enums, and I am required to duplicate code. The solution would be to override the methods.

Overriding super methods


You can extends an Enum method. I enhanced the example above as such : 
public enum DateFormats {

    SHORT{
        @Override
        boolean isSuitable(String dateString) {
            return super.isSuitable(dateString) && dateString.length() < 10;
        }},
    MEDIUM{
        @Override
        boolean isSuitable(String dateString) {
            return super.isSuitable(dateString) && dateString.length() > 10 && dateString.split(" ").length < 15;
        }},
    FULL{
        @Override
        boolean isSuitable(String dateString) {
            if (dateString.contains("AM") || dateString.contains("PM")) return true;
            return super.isSuitable(dateString) && dateString.length() > 10 && dateString.split(" ").length > 15;
        }},
    CUSTOMIZED;

     boolean isSuitable(String dateString){
        return (!((dateString == null ) || (dateString.trim().length()==0)));
     }
}

As you can see the "isSuitable" function is not abstract anymore, and the enums SHORT/MEDIUM/FULL override it and call it with "super.isSuitable".

I also added a new enum named "CUSTOMIZED" which does not define the "isSuitable" method.

This method is much nicer.


Enums and JAXB


I wrote a small JAXB example with a store and products. The target audience of the product is an enum. In order to export the enum with namespaced JAXB I wrote the following annotation : 
@XmlEnum
    @XmlType(namespace = "http://mograbi.co.il/xsds/mogi-code-samples/jaxb-code-sample/1.0/store")
    public enum TARGET_AUDIENCE{
        CHILDREN, STUDENTS, ADULTS
    }

JAXB can survive without the @XmlEnum annotation.
Note that the definition is on the enum type and not the usage (field).
This means that using 3rd-parties enums is not suitable for this example.


Enum and Hibernate


In order to save the same object into a Database with Hibernate I would annotate it with : 
@Enumerated(EnumType.STRING)

I specify EnumType.STRING because by default hibernate uses Integer in order to save the enum ordinal. This means - if I change the order of the enum, my database is corrupted, so by default I assign the STRING value of the enum.

I think that the STRING value is extracted with the "name" field of the enum, so it is quite flexible if changing is required.

String Enum Conversions


You can easily convert between Enum and String.
In order to get the String value of an enum, use "name()", and in order to get the Enum equivalent of the String use "valueOf()".
Using the "name()" instead of "toString()" is preferred since it is the reverse operation done by "valueOf".

Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE aud = Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE.CHILDREN;
        System.out.println("aud.name() = " + aud.name());

        aud = Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE.valueOf("STUDENTS");
        System.out.println("aud = " + aud);

It is important to note that valueOf is case sensitive and throws "IllegalArgumentException" if an enum is not found.

Enum and Reflection


Manipulating Enum with reflection is very easy. 

Class aClass = Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE.class;
        if (aClass.isEnum()){
            Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE[] constants = aClass.getEnumConstants();
            for (Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE constant : constants) {
                System.out.println("constant = " + constant);
            }
        }

        Book.TARGET_AUDIENCE audience = Enum.valueOf(aClass, "STUDENTS");
        System.out.println("audience = " + audience);

title.__text: My First API

content.__text:
As I promised, I wrote a small API that can be shared with other sites.

In a previous blog I explored a Javascript API with tweeter. After that I decided to write an API of my own. My API is a WYSIWYG text editor.



The reason I chose a text editor is because it is an interesting challenge, and since I couldn't find one I really liked. You can see my text editor at my site.

Currently (16-FEB-2009) it doesn't include all the features I would like it to have.
For example
  • It does not have a file upload (Especially useful with image insertions)
  • It does not have a table insert (Although it is very easy)
  • It does not automatically detect URLs.
  • It does not support mathematical symbols
  • It does not have drawing capabilities
  • Auto save which is automatically scheduled by editor and fired as event to listeners

There are probably more features, however the above are the ones I am going to implement soon.
Except for the drawing capabilities, I already know how to implement them.

My API


As we've seen in my prior blog, the goal is to have a pure Javascript implementation, which is configurable enough (especially CSS-wise).
In order to check that my API is good, and configurable, I am already using it at another site I wrote linked here to a demo version.

The code needed to use in another site looks something like this :





And that's it!
Actually, the example above has some configuration code included. You can remove it..

So lets see what I did.

  • First of all, note that it is pure Javascript. There are no specific HTML elements needed. The "parentNode" shown in the example is an optional configuration
  • The styles are separated to a CSS file linked above. At my site, you can select a different skin I wrote and see the editor with a different skin
  • The Javascript itself is modular, and available in a single file (no multiple inclusion required). You can read the specific text editor code here and see the entire file available here
  • buttonsConf - is a configuration for the buttons. By default I decided to have nothing in the buttons. The CSS defines background images for it. However - some of you might want to insert the images as inner HTML for some reason so I enabled it. The names of the images is predefined so all you need to do is point the editor to the base folder of the images and it will append the image name.

Tweeter also had a special page with a form that constructs the code for you. It will probably be nice to have it included somewhere - and I am planning on having such a thing in the future. However I assume you know how to write it so I won't waste a blog post for this issue.

Another thing Tweeter has but this example does not is Ajax usage - which is needed in order to fetch data from Tweeter (the account's tweets) but not required for every Javascript API.

title.__text: Solving the Javascript - Resources Bridge Problem

content.__text:
The Problem

When you use Javascript in a site that supports internalization (I18N), you will come across problems combining the two.

Ajax makes this problem even more real.
However, while writing my site, I came across a cool solution I thought I should share.

Most people I know find themselves duplicating massive code lines just to pass the information along the way. They create the Javascript while using undeclared variables, and then declare them in JSPs.

My Final Solution



After trying several methods, I decided to use the following.
I wrote a servlet that reads the resources.properties bundle according to locale set in session.


Then it reads the resource file, and translates it to Javascript.
The request to this servlet is declared as Javascript.
For example - it might look like this :




The servlet must do several things in order for this to work.
  1. It must set encoding to UTF-8
  2. It must make sure it writes a valid Javascript content. - this means we must escape characters which are invalid.

My current result is shown below. It contains some code related to my framework, but I believe it is still readable so I did not edit it for this blog.

public class ResourcesServlet extends HttpServlet{
public static IMogiLogger logger = MogiLogUtils.getLogger(ResourcesServlet.class);

@Override
protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest req, HttpServletResponse resp) throws ServletException, IOException {
   String baseName = req.getParameter("baseName");
   String locale = Resources.getLocale();
   logger.debug("returning : " + baseName + " for locale : " + locale);
   try{
       ResourceBundle resourceBundle;
       resp.setCharacterEncoding("UTF-8");
       resp.setContentType("text/javascript;charset=UTF-8");
       Writer writer = resp.getWriter();
       ResourceBundleIdentifier bundleIdentifier = new ResourceBundleIdentifier(baseName, locale);
       if (Resources.bundleMap.containsKey(bundleIdentifier)){
           resourceBundle = Resources.bundleMap.get(bundleIdentifier);
       }else{
           resourceBundle = ResourceBundle.getBundle(baseName,new Locale(Resources.getLocale()));
       }
       for (String s : resourceBundle.keySet()) {
           // need to modify it to Javascript
           String jsKey = s.replaceAll("\\-","_").replaceAll("\\.","_");

           writer.append("var ").append(jsKey).append("=\"").append(resourceBundle.getString(s).replaceAll("\"","\\\\\"")).append("\";\n");
       }
   }catch(Exception e){
       StringWriter s = new StringWriter();
       e.printStackTrace(new PrintWriter(s));
       resp.sendError(404,s.toString());
   }
}
}


As you can see there are 2 places where I make adjustments.
I escape the keys and replace character '.' and '-' to '_'.
I escape the values' quotation marks.

This way I don't need to worry. I update my resource file once, and I can use it anywhere.

Other Solutions I Tried Along the Way



Until I reached the solution above, I tried other methods.
Since I am an Ajax junkie I thought to make an Ajax call from my script.

However this is very limiting when you want to expose your Javascript as API.
It also requires a lot of code, and IDEs won't support refactoring.
So I didn't like this method.

.jsp.js Files



Another method I tried still required a lot of code, however it turned out to be useful for other things.

I set a filter in tomcat like this :


    
        
        
            /jsps/js/*
            *.jsp



So now all my .js fukes will be treated as .jsps so I can inject java code directly to them.

It proved helpful when I needed string to be resolved like paths.
For example - when you write a login with Ajax, you will probably want to use 
 document.location = some_path

in order to move from that page after validation.
So this solution is good for resolving the "some_path" value (since it is context dependent).

References



The code for the ResourceServlet is available in my repository.

title.__text: Understanding Javascript API with Embedding Twitter

content.__text:
The web is bombarded with APIs, web-services, gadgets, widgets, robots...

You can add to your site snippets from : twitter, blogger, google (maps/docs/reader/and what not..), flickr, facebook, and the list goes on and on. Moreover, you should add these to your site.

If you're squared, you're there.


The question I want to answer is - how do you do it?
Today, I will show you a little embedding example from twitter, and in the near future I will add more entries dealing with implementations, documentations and so on.


Embedding Twitter



Twitter is becoming more important by the second. It's called the fastest growing social network. They also have a blog in blogger. So I created an account under guymograbi, followed some people, and twitted a bit, and then got down to business.

You can use my username - so you don't have to create a twitter account in order to follow this blog. All the links are available to non-twitter-users. Just type "guymograbi" whenever you need a username.

Where to start



If a site is written well, you will probably find a link to "share","embed me", "widgets","api" and so on close by. You can use ctrl+f to simply search the page.

Twitter decided to call this "goodies" - just scroll down.
Note that this link is also available in the homepage - so you don't need to be logged in. It might seem strange to you now, but actually this is the way to go.
It's exactly these type of things that shows how well your code is.


Other than the goodies link, there's an API link, which is relevant to us, but not to this article. Maybe the next one.



Once you click the goodies reach this page



You can find 2 useful links there - Buttons and Widgets. The buttons are a quick way to enable people to follow you - which is what most people will probably use. So this is probably the first thing we can learn about APIs. Publish some cool buttons that will activate some small but important feature in your web.

The "follow me" feature is activated by a link either way.. so giving people a button requires no real effort from twitter, and makes the site much more user friendly to developers - the most important social community :)

I would love it if you will comment about the feature you might expose with a button in your site.

Once we are done with buttons, lets move to widgets.

If a site is written well - a widget will be as effortless as a button. Since twitter seems to be written very well (so far. The real test will be when we examine their APIs). So you should take this into consideration when you implement your site - we will talk about implementations in the next article.

So I click widgets. I see "widgets for my website" - which is what I want. I click it. If I click "myspace" or "facebook" I get a boring wizard.




I choose the Profile Widget link, change the username if you want to - you can try "guymograbi" if you don't want to create your own account - and click "finish & grab code" below.

Important to note here that if you're logged in, twitter will automatically fill in your username in the username field. If you're not logged in, it will populate that field with "twitter". There is a "twitter" user, so you can simply use it. This is yet another example that proves you know how to write excellent code. Make note to yourself that demo parameters are important to the experience, great for developing and even support.

A window opens with code snippet to copy, some links, and result section for a preview.



We won't go over the whole page - since its not that interesting.
What is interesting is the fact that any other widget other than "Profile Widget" would result with a similar outcome, differentiating only by parameters. While the Profile widget requires username, other widgets require other input.

Disecting the code



Ok - so the content of the snippet is what we really want to dig into.






I think the most amazing thing is that it is all written in JavaScript.

The snippet includes an import to the JavaScript directly from twitter. So if their site is down, the widget won't work.

Afterward, we see a new object named TWTR.Widget. They use a namespace here which is good.

This object is given 8 variables. Each of which can tell us something important.

  • version - this is probably the most important variable. Versioning is important for backward compatibility. Once you expose an API, you should always consider people who use it when you upgrade. Looking back, we can see this number also appearing in the javascript include statement. Just look at the src path.

  • type - This is the second most important parameter. This parameter differentiates the type of the widget. Changing it will require modifying some other parameters - as we remember the different input parameters used for other widgets. We know that for the profile widget we will need the username.

  • rpp,interval,width,height,theme - All of these decide the look and feel of the widget. Personally I would wrap them together, but it doesn't really matter. From this we learn it is important to not leave the style control to the user. This kind of menu might just be useful to any kind of widget. Color selections, Font selections and so on. This might require some serious work before you expose your interface. So make sure to allocate enough time.

  • features - uh! We always assume people will want features. However, flagging features on/off is very useful to everyone. Its part of the agile development which is so popular these days. This tells us that twitter is quite stable and modular.



It's amazing how much you can learn from usage without actually seeing the underlying implementation.
From this alone you can see that twitter is using agile development methods, with clear separation of functionality and appearance. It has backward compatibility, so we can rest assure this widget will continue to function even after they upgrade.

GOOD! Way to go twitter!

Underlying Implementation



You might be tempted to go to http://widgets.twimg.com/j/2/widget.js and start reading. However, what you will find there is a loooooot of unreadable JavaScript. It is unreadable because twitter are doing a great job. (not kidding).

You see, JavaScript should be written in components just like packages in Java. Then you get a really complicated hierarchy of components divided to a lot of files. To make life easier on the browser, the best thing you can do is "compile" JavaScript to result a smaller file. That file in not readable and contains a lot of infrastructure code you should not care about.

However, to save you the trouble, I will write some guesses I have of how they implemented it. In the following article I will try to find out which they actually use.

Easiest



The easiest way I can think of is to send a request to the server with all the parameters given in the function. The result should be an HTML text. Javascript should add this HTML to your page and that's it!

Its easy because it requires a small amount of HTML that is used to send a request and add HTML to your page. Both tasks are basically easy and I will show how to do this when the time comes.

Moreover, this method is applicable to sites you didn't even write! This is in fact considered to be a security problem with JavaScript but I will talk about it in a special JavaScript article.

This method is also good for caching which you probably want.

Pure Javascript



JavaScript can do just about everything you need it. It can construct an entire page. So the JavaScript can basically construct the entire HTML. Sometimes, even I prefer this option - for example populating an entire table will require much less code in JavaScript than any other.

However, most of the time, you're better of writing HTML in HTML and leaving JavaScript to do other stuff since the HTML might get complicated. Nonetheless, there are great JavaScript libraries out there that simplify it for you. YUI (Yahoo! UI) is a popular example, and here is a demo for it showing a draggable popup, darkening effect and more.

Next Articles



That's it for today. I know this article is pretty basic stuff but you have to start somewhere. The next article on the topic will be after I wrote some API myself with examples on my site.

A tribute to JavaScript



JavaScript is the most widely used client-side scripting language and by far the most important thing you will learn while writing web applications. It doesn't even matter which language you use to write your site, you will want to know JavaScript. There are alternatives like VBScript and JScript, but none of them compare to JavaScript.

It is unlikely to find a web-app related article without JavaScript. I will most definitely dedicate entire pages to it. There are some environments that don't support it, but there's a continuing effort to minimize the gap.

Examples for environments that don't support it are :

  • Mobile Phone browsers

  • Sometimes people disable it due to some security problems
    • . These security issues are mostly irrelevant if you don't exaggerate your JavaScript usage.

title.__text: Setting up an environment for a Webapp

content.__text:
It's sometimes easier to dive into an existing project since everything is set up for you and all that is left is the fun part - coding.
A lot of developers don't even care about the basics and the infrastructure.

In this blog I summarize a few good things you will want to do with a webapp project in Maven, that is running under Tomcat.
This article assumes you already downloaded Tomcat, and generate a webapp project with maven.


SAX Parser exception


When I started my Tomcat, I got an exception (without doing anything).
The exception wrote : 
Jan 13, 2010 5:03:11 PM org.apache.tomcat.util.digester.Digester fatalError
SEVERE: Parse Fatal Error at line 1 column 2: Content is not allowed in prolog.
org.xml.sax.SAXParseException: Content is not allowed in prolog.
at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.util.ErrorHandlerWrapper.createSAXParseException(ErrorHandlerWrapper.java:195)


and somewhere below I saw a reference to host-manager.xml.
When I opened this file there was no xml inside, but Java code.
I couldn't really find solutions online, and decided to simply rename the file to something else than XML suffix. It made the problem go away.

Changing the default welcome page


When you go to http://localhost:8080 you reach a Tomcat homepage. That's not really nice. What you want to do is go to webapps/ROOT and change the index.jsp.

I prefer to go into WEB-INF and modify the web.xml, adding to it : 

    
        my_homepage.jsp



And then I simply write my_hompage. which is always the same for me : 
Available locations here are :

<%!
public String show(String webapp, HttpServletRequest request) {
String location = request.getRequestURL().toString() + webapp;
return ""+webapp+"";
}
%>
Available locations here are :

<%=show("app1", request)%>
<%=show("app2", request)%>
<%=show("app3", request)%>


All you need to do is change app1,app2,app3 to some real context paths you have in your Tomcat and spice this page with some CSS.

If you have only one webapp, you can simply redirect.


Deploying the application


When I click install, I want my WAR to reach the local Tomcat.
It seems that Tomcat wrote a nice HTTP API for such things.
But before you can use it, go to conf/tomcat-users.xml.

If there's no user with manager role, add something like the following



And now try the following address : 
http://localhost:8080/manager/list


When you are prompted for user/pass simply type the admin admin, or whichever name/pass you wrote in tomcat-users.xml file.

This will show you a list of all running applications. In my case it showed me the following : 
OK - Listed applications for virtual host localhost
/:running:0:ROOT
/manager:running:0:D:/dev_env/tomcat-5.5/server/webapps/manager
/webdav:running:0:webdav
/servlets-examples:running:0:servlets-examples
/guy_mograbi:running:0:guy_mograbi
/tomcat-docs:running:0:tomcat-docs
/jsp-examples:running:0:jsp-examples
/balancer:running:0:balancer


So in just the same way, you can deploy a war.

Add the following to your pom.xml 

    org.codehaus.mojo
    tomcat-maven-plugin
    
        /guy_mograbi
        admin
        admin
        true
        UTF-8
    
    
        
            
                deploy-only
                
            
            install
        
    



What we see here is :
  • Invocation of maven-tomcat-plugin with goal deploy-only
  • path - the context of your application. By default it is the artifactId, in my case I had to override it, however you might want to use the default
  • admin/username - like in tomcat-users.xml.
  • charset - just to be on the safe side, I decided to add UTF-8. My site supports many languages. However I did not check if this is really necessary
  • execution happens on install phase


I left the "list" goal there for you to try. The output should be the same as when you tried it in the browser.

I18N support


I think it is always wise to have multi-language support, even if you don't use it.

I always do the following just to make sure things will go smoothly :
  • In my jsps I make sure the following line is in the header 


  •  In conf/server.xml I make sure that Connector on port 8080 has the attribute 

    URIEncoding="UTF-8"
    . Some of you might prefer 

    useBodyEncodingURI="true"
    although I recommend the first one. 
  •  Put all your resources in property bundles - use the folder src/main/native2ascii. Use the ResourceBundle to read them. - IDEs also have a nice support so it's a good way to go. However, in order to make it work, you will need to use the native2ascii plugin like this :

                process-resources
            
        

The only thing you might want to change is the "dest" property.   
That's all 


Ok, now you're good to go. Have fun coding.

title.__text: Setting a classloader in Maven Plugin

content.__text:
I often find myself in need to load classes that I just compiled when I write a Maven plug-in. Take for example the surefire plug-in - the one that runs your tests - they need all the compiled code accessible in run-time. I find it most useful to discover bugs that otherwise would be discovered at run-time.

For example - We have an XML that points to a method in a class. It would be good to load the class and check if the method exists. Maybe that class should implement an interface - we can check that as well. All these plug-ins have one thing in common. They all require manipulations on the class-loader. In this article I will show you my generic ClassLoader suitable for all plug-ins and available at my nexus repository (http://www.mograbi.co.il/nexus at mogi.code.maven:maven-plugins-utils artifact) .



The interface I provide contains the following methods :


/**
*
* @param project - we need the project in order to discover
* all dependencies and build output directory
*/
public MavenPluginClassLoaderHandler(MavenProject project);

/**
* Will change {@link Thread#getContextClassLoader()} with a new {@link ClassLoader}
* that contains all dependencies and classes directory
*/
public void addAllArtifactsToClassLoader();

/**
* Should return the original classloader before the change
*/
public void restoreClassLoader();



The Idea for the flow is the expressed in the following pseudo-code



// Maven Plugin execute implementation

execute{

MavenPluginClassLoaderHandler clHandler = new();
clHandler.addAllArtifactsToClassLoader();

//do what you need to do here. Use Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader()
// wherever a class loader is needed

// when done, need to restore the previous class loader just to be safe
clHandler.restoreClassLoader();
}



Implementation



It's a tricky business handling ClassLoader but since this is a MavenPlugin we will keep it as simple as possible. We will use URLClassLoader for our needs.

The implementation will look something like this

Implementation for addAllArtifactsToClassPath


logger.debug("adding all artifacts to classLoader");
Collection urls = new ArrayList();

//noinspection unchecked
for (Artifact artifact : (Collection) project.getArtifacts()) {
try {
urls.add(artifact.getFile().toURI().toURL());
} catch (MalformedURLException e) {
// logger.error(e);
}
}

try {
urls.add(new File(project.getBuild().getOutputDirectory()).toURI().toURL());
} catch (MalformedURLException e) {
logger.error(e);
}

logger.debug("urls = \n" + urls.toString().replace(",","\n")) ;

Thread.currentThread().setContextClassLoader(new URLClassLoader(urls.toArray(new URL[urls.size()]),original));



As you can see we first take all dependencies from project using project.getArtifacts(). This might seem a bit weird at first, because there's also getDependencies() but the difference is Dependencies are XML Entities, while Artifacts are the file representation behind the dependencies. It took me a while to accept that concept.

Afterward, I also add the location of the compile output directory "classes" by invoking project.getBuild().getOutputDirectory(). Again, might seem a bit odd at first.

At the end I create a new ClassLoader containing all the locations I found.

The restore implementation is even easier



ClassLoader cl = Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader();



public void restoreClassLoader(){
Thread.currentThread().setContextClassLoader(cl);
}






References



  • About ClassLoader from JavaWorld

  • About URLClassLoader from Core Java Technologies Tech Tip
  • My nexus repository where you can find the JAR and Sources.

content.__text:
During my work at Quest Software I worked on a project that required all logging messages in a properties file PER PACKAGE!!!

I know it is perfectly reasonable to replace hard-coded strings with properties files, but I always had a single properties file per project, and here, each package had a different file.

Our projects were built with Maven, so our folder structure there was well defined.
I took advantage of this to write a small Intellij plugin that opens the correct properties file.

The use-case is : I am writing some code in a class, and I want to log something, I have a menu with "Open LogResources.properties"




First I did the tutorial, where you write a hello world plugin and search google.

Then I started working on the plugin, starting with the tutorial output, and modified it.

The result was the following.
The code basically find the "src/main/java" combination of folders and opens the appropriate folder in "src/main/resources".

The source 



public class SayHelloAction extends AnAction {
    //    Logger logger = Logger.getInstance(SayHelloAction.class.toString());
    @NonNls
    private static final String SRC = "src/";


    public void actionPerformed(AnActionEvent e) {
        DataContext dataContext = e.getDataContext();
        Module data = DataKeys.MODULE.getData(dataContext);

        VirtualFile vFile = DataKeys.VIRTUAL_FILE.getData(dataContext);
        Project project = DataKeys.PROJECT.getData(dataContext);
        FileEditorManager fileEditorManager = FileEditorManager.getInstance(project);

        String fileName = vFile.getPath();


        Application application = ApplicationManager.getApplication();
        HelloWorldApplicationComponent helloWorldComponent =
                application.getComponent(HelloWorldApplicationComponent.class);


        PsiFile logResourcesFile;
        if (fileName.indexOf("src/main/") > 0) {
//            logger.info("assuming maven project");
            // go to the resource folder .. remember the path
            Stack stack = new Stack();
            int i = 100;

            VirtualFile parent = vFile.getParent();
            while (i > 0 && parent != null && (!parent.getName().equals("main") || parent.findChild("java") == null)) {
                // I assume this is a good enough condition to determine we reached the turning point
                stack.push(parent.getName());
                parent = parent.getParent();
                i--; // some limit to avoid infinite loop
            }

            stack.pop(); // removing the "java" folder name
            // if we are here it means we are in main. we need to create resources
            PsiDirectory file = PsiManager.getInstance(project).findDirectory(parent);

            PsiDirectory resources = findOrCreateDirectory(file, "resources");
            while (!stack.isEmpty()) {
                String folderName = stack.pop();
                resources = findOrCreateDirectory(resources, folderName);
            }

            logResourcesFile = findOrCreateFile(resources, "LogResources.properties");


        } else {
//            logger.info("assuming non maven project");
            PsiFile pFile = PsiManager.getInstance(project).findFile(vFile);

            PsiDirectory psiDirectory = pFile.getParent();
            if ((logResourcesFile = psiDirectory.findFile("LogResources.properties")) == null) {
                psiDirectory.createFile("LogResources.properties");
                logResourcesFile = psiDirectory.findFile("LogResources.properties");
            }
            VirtualFileManager.getInstance().refresh(true);
            VirtualFileManager.getInstance().fireReadOnlyModificationAttempt(logResourcesFile.getVirtualFile());

        }
        fileEditorManager.openFile(logResourcesFile.getVirtualFile(), true);

        fileEditorManager.getSelectedTextEditor().getDocument().setReadOnly(false);


//        helloWorldComponent.sayHello();
    }

    private PsiDirectory findOrCreateDirectory(PsiDirectory parent, String s) {
        PsiDirectory child = parent.findSubdirectory(s);
        if (child == null) {
            child = parent.createSubdirectory(s);
        }

        return child;
    }

    private PsiFile findOrCreateFile(PsiDirectory parent, String s) {
        PsiFile child = parent.findFile(s);
        if (child == null) {
            child = parent.createFile(s);
        }

        return child;
    }
}


Note that this won't support tests - however I assumed tests don't need to be supported.

plugin.xml



Along with the source you have the plugin.xml. here it is :

    FglamLogResources
    This plugin do nothing
    1.0
    JetBrains
    
    
        
            com.intellij.tutorial.helloWorld.HelloWorldApplicationComponent



Conclusion



The plugin was a great help for everyone.
I had a lot of hard time to write it and I bet I have a zillion mistakes - it was not easy at all since this area lacks of documentation. I had to learn code samples from forums where people post errors they have.

But it was worth the while. :)

title.__text: My Application Maven Plugin

content.__text:
Maven is a great tool, but I find sometimes it is missing little, very helpful things.

Documentation for example, is lacking. However this was improved by version 2.0.

However, the thing I find missing most of all is a plugin that takes my jar and all needed dependencies, build a "run.bat", zips and deploys.

The assembly plugin claims be good for this purpose, but I didn't like it. First of all it has an external XML, and my first experience with it was frustrating.
I couldn't find a way to generate my "run.bat". (how annoying can it be to maintain classpath in scripts?)

So I wrote my own, quite useful, plugin. I call it the application plugin.




Goals



My plugin has the following goals :

  • make-app - gathers all jars into folder and generates run.bat
  • zip - zips the generated directory from "make-app".
  • attach - attaches the zip as secondary artifact.
  • release - places the zip in a location available to the entire company. I prefer to the Maven Repository since teams like QA don't need to know what the repository (or maven) is.


Additional Features



Debug , Pause , Suspend, Bat, KSH



How many times did you want to set the properties for remote debug but forgot what they are?
How many times did you start running the application but forgot to give the debug properties in the command line ?


In my plugin I added boolean flags to add the debug properties for remote debug (you can also decide the port). Suspend allows you to specify if the debug should suspend the application.

Pause is very useful when you need to see the entire output before the console closes. I use true as default. It's always good to have one last check in the console that I am ready to close.

I also automatically produce scripts to run for windows (.bat) and unix (.ksh).
Even though I write in Java, sometimes the QA will need to verify other platforms (verifying other JVMs for example).

Copying Dependencies



How did copy the dependencies ?
I used Google's execution code.


Parameters



My "run" script supports several types of parameters.

  • Built In - parameters which will always be sent to main
  • Extenral / Manual - parameters that are appended to the run command. "run.bat a b c".


To achieve external parameters I had to perform loops in batch and ksh.
The output look like this :

Batch 



set ARGS=
:arguments
set ARGS=%ARGS% %1
shift
if not "%1"=="" goto arguments


Ksh


I didn't find a way to perform this in ksh. (I don't have a lot of knowledge on the subject).

Dynamic Output Folder



Later I was requested to add a dynamic output folder.
The trick I did here was : let the user declare the name of the folder he will write into. This name should be constant.
Then, in the "run" script, I will append a "rename" algorithm to append that folder name the timestamp.
The code looks like this

Batch 



rem RENAME OUTPUT DIRECTORY TO OUTPUT WITH TIME

rem SHOULD REPLACE "place_orig_output_name_here" WITH OUTPUT FOLDER NAME FROM JETIF.PROPERTIES
set orig_output_name=place_orig_output_name_here

rem set date to variable CDATE
FOR /F "TOKENS=1* DELIMS= " %%A IN ('DATE/T') DO SET CDATE=%%B
echo CDATE=%CDATE%
FOR /F "TOKENS=1,2 eol=/ DELIMS=/ " %%A IN ('DATE/T') DO SET mm=%%B
FOR /F "TOKENS=1,2 DELIMS=/ eol=/" %%A IN ('echo %CDATE%') DO SET dd=%%B
FOR /F "TOKENS=2,3 DELIMS=/ " %%A IN ('echo %CDATE%') DO SET yyyy=%%B

rem set time to a variable CTIME
FOR /F %%A IN ('echo %time%') DO SET CTIME=%%A
echo CTIME=%CTIME%
FOR /F "DELIMS=':'" %%A IN ('echo %CTIME%') DO SET hour=%%A
echo hour=%hour%
FOR /F "TOKENS=2 DELIMS=':' " %%A IN ('echo %CTIME%') DO SET minute=%%A
echo minute=%minute%

FOR /F "TOKENS=3 DELIMS=':' " %%A IN ('echo %CTIME%') DO SET littleTime=%%A
echo littleTime=%littleTime%

FOR /F "DELIMS='.' " %%A IN ('echo %littleTime%') DO SET seconds=%%A
echo seconds=%seconds%
FOR /F "TOKENS=2 DELIMS='.' " %%A IN ('echo %littleTime%') DO SET millis=%%A
echo millis=%millis%


SET my_date=%yyyy%y-%mm%m-%dd%d@%hour%h-%minute%m-%seconds%s-%millis%ms

echo %my_date%

mv %orig_output_name% output#%my_date%


Unix 



year=`date +%Y`
month=`date +%m`
day_of_month=`date +%d`
hour=`date +%H`
minute=`date +%M`
second=`date +%S`
new_name=output#${year}-${month}-${day_of_month}@${hour}-${minute}-${second}

# should replace "place_orig_output_name_here" with original filename
mv place_orig_output_name_here $new_name


Gotta love Unix's elegance.

Conclusion



Maven lacks a simple plugin to gather your runnables and generate a run script.
Writing one is fun and quite simple for experienced plugin developers.
I keep getting requirements for this plugin, so I assume it is quite popular.


References



  • Assemyl Plugin
  • Application Plugin Documentation in My Site
  • My Maven Repository for Download and Sources
  • Google's Mojo Executor

title.__text: Jetif  and My Jetif Maven Plugin

content.__text:
Small Introduction to Jetif



Over the years, I found myself writing server code for webapps. While having fun not worrying about UI, I came across a problem. The QA couldn't check my code, they had to have a UI.

You might suggest the QA write code - but that means integration.

What you need in such a case is something similar to JUnit but only with some kind of User Interface. And then came Jetif.



JUnit GUI


My first thought was to build or find a GUI for JUnit.
It seems there was once such a thing, which is now deprecated.
Maintaining GUI is hard work. So I searched for something easier to maintain.

Jetif


Jetif has a nice take on things.
You have an XML (of course) that defines your test cases.
Each test case can call methods, and give it parameters.

Jetif will read this XML, run these methods with reflection, and build a nice report.

There is of course the issue of serializing complex object as method arguments.
But you can use Spring to work around that.

Making Life Easier with Maven


I couldn't find any existing plugin to Jetif in Maven. So I wrote several plugins.

Jetif archetype



First of all - creating the basic layout.
Jetif project have at least 5 regular files :

  1. A Java class
  2. A Unit test
  3. XML for test-cases. ( at least one )
  4. pom.xml with Jetif depedency(of course)
  5. jetif.properties (optional, but always nice to have)


And of course : properties files have predefined keys, and XML have defined XSDs.
Lazy developers will copy paste them from one project to another.
I am not lazy.

5 files are enough for me to decide to have an archetype.
So I did one.

Lifecycle



There are several things I will always want to do in a Jetif project.


  • Compile, Test, Jar - of course
  • Gather all the Jar dependencies to a single folder
  • Generate "bat" file and "ksh" file (for windows and unix).
  • ZIP this folder
  • Deploy it to some location where the QA have access to it.


If I do these things automatically, I guarantee that the QA will always be able to test the latest version of my code in an automated environment that they can expand as much as they like.

So I wrote the Jetif lifecycle. Now all I have to do in a pom.xml in order to get all of these done is write
 
 jetif

and that's it.

Conclusion



Jetif is an easy to use user interface I like to use when I need to release my code to QA.

Integrating it with Maven and Spring makes my life as easy as can be leaving me the fun part of writing the application code and letting the rest happen automatically.

The way I see it - everyone benefit from it.

  • The QA don't have to wait to long for something they can test.
  • I don't have to work hard on a user interface - with spring the maintenance goes to zero as well.
  • My boss sees results really fast.
  • QA does not need to write code - however they can...


Technical Details



My components.xml for this plugin looks something like this 


    
        
            org.apache.maven.lifecycle.mapping.LifecycleMapping
            jetif
            org.apache.maven.lifecycle.mapping.DefaultLifecycleMapping
            
                
                    org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-resources-plugin:resources
                    org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-compiler-plugin:compile
                    org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-resources-plugin:testResources
                    org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-compiler-plugin:testCompile
                    
                    org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-surefire-plugin:test
                    
                        org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-jar-plugin:jar,
                        backend.plugins:backend-application-plugin:1.0.3:make-jetif-app,
                        backend.plugins:backend-application-plugin:1.0.3:zip
                    
                    
                    
                        backend.plugins:backend-application-plugin:1.0.3:deploy




The "application-plugin" is explained in another blog

References



  • Maven Archetype Plugin

  • Jetif Home Site

  • How to write Maven Lifecycle

  • My Maven Repository for sources and download

title.__text: Cleaner Java Code with CGLIB

content.__text:
Cleaner Code With CGLib

ASM - allows you to generate byte code at runtime.
It might not mean much to you at the moment, but this is a strong ability.
For example - this ability allowed the creation of the Groovy language.

Today I will show how hibernate uses ASM.

If You Use Hibernate, You Use CGLib! - Lazy Load With Hibernate

Lets say we have an Office object with One-To-Many relationship to another object called Employees.
The Office object will have a field that looks like this :


class Office { 
 @Column
 String name;
 
 @Column
 String address;

 @OneToMany(mappedBy = "office")
 Collection employees = new ... ;

 // getters and setters
 public Collection getEmployees{return employees;}
}

I also created a field for Name and Address.
The most important thing in the code above is the getter for employees, note that it does not run any query.

Search Feature By Name/Address Does Not Require Employees

Now lets assume for a minute I am writing a "search office by name or address" feature
For this feature, we only need the "name" and "address" of each Office.
We do not need the employees field.
So it will be better for performance that we do not query the database for them.
We can tell hibernate to not query for the empolyees unless we use the getter "getEmployees". To achieve this, lets add "Lazy" definition to the "employees field annotation" 


 @OneToMany(mappedBy = "office", fetch=FetchType.LAZY)
 Collection employees = new ... ;

Hibernate uses two queries to create the object we need, however - when you use lazy loading
this second query will execute only when we invoke the getter.
The queries will be :

  1. Query to fetch the office
  2. Query to fetch the employees when we use the getter

How does hibernate detect that I invoked the getter ?
The getter is a normal getter, it does not reference hibernate or the database in any way..
To understand the answer, you should stop the application in debug to see the runtime classname of the Office object.
You should see something like this :

packageName.Office$EnhancedByCGLIB$@

The field is standard information for any object and is not relevant in this discussion.
The ID is some unique identifier generated by CGLIB and is also of no real importance to us.
The important thing to see is that we didn't get Office, but some other class.
This class was obviously not generated in compile time - we can check the contents of the jars to verify - so what happens here ?

Hibernate generates a new class in runtime.
This new class is called Office$$EnhancedByCGLIB$$ and it has the exact same API as my Office class,
but at runtime, a different code is running.
This code is the "enhanced" class generated by CGLib.
The enhanced class has a reference to the Database and when it executes the getter for employees another query is executed.

When Should I Use CGLib?

It's always hard to identify when you should or should not use some technology in your code.
For example - if I need a single connection to the Database for a small query,
it would be a shame to use Spring in order to initialize a connection pool and run in a different thread.

I find CGLIB most useful in configuration objects.
I also used it to extend selenium.

So for configuration purposes, I want my application to have code like this : 


 class Configuration{
   String username; 
   String password; 
   // getter and setter ... 
 }

 Configuration myConf = new Configuration(); 
 // myConf.getUsername() -- will get the username
 // myconf.getPassword() -- will get the password

This way I can decouple my configuration fields from the configuration mechanism.
It does not matter if I use a JSON file, a YAML file, environment variable etc..
I can actually use them all!
I actually used this mechanism a couple of times, and it is quite useful.
It is especially useful when you want well structured objects for configuration and to easily initialize them with default values.
You can see it in My Play!Framework 2 Survival Kit!

References

  • ASM in Wikipedia
  • CGLIB
  • Hibernate lazy load

title.__text: Steps Project

content.__text:
How do you tackle a big project? You take baby steps.

A while ago I searched for a project management application since I have all these things I want to do and I have to list them down in an organized manner.

I discovered there's no such application that I like. All are simply schedule based or a task list. And that is not my take on the meaning of a project.

title.__text: Test Module for Play!Framework

content.__text:
The Test Module for Play!Framework helps you write tests quicker, is a cleaner and reusable manner.

Play provides an environment for testing. However that environment is full of hard-coded strings, and the code you write is neither reusable nor maintainable.

When you start a new Play application, Play generates a sample code for you that looks like this : 



Response response = GET("/");

 assertIsOk(response);

 assertContentType("text/html", response);

 assertCharset("utf-8", response);

I have several problems with this code.

  • The path "/" is unclear.. In order to know what you are testing, you need to check the "routes" file.

  • Calling actions with path string makes tests hard to maintain and develop. If you have a signature with many parameters (for example, signup form or survey form) it will be hard to write the path. If I will change an argument's name in the controller's signature I will need to modify all related path strings.

  • Why am I specifying "GET"? Why am I not specifying the method I want to call, and let Play figure it out by itself? As a developer it's natural to me to call a method instead of constructing a URL.

  • It is not Object oriented enough, and hence the code is less reusable. I would probably want to check that the response is OK many times. maybe even on every response. If the code was OO I could override "GET" and add a check that the response is ok.

  • Strings are hard-coded. For example "text/html" and "utf-8". This is error prone.

  • Play already does all the things I specify. So why not in the tests?


    • My Wishes

    I wish I could simply call the controller's function.

    In the example above, the path "/" will direct me to controller "Application" and action "index". I wish I could simply call Application.index() and that's it. However, for someone outside of Play it will be hard to implement if not impossible.

    The reason for it being so hard lies in the instrumentation technic which is massively used all around Play and the fact that the methods are static.

    I will not elaborate this topic here, nor will I talk about why Play chose to implement the actions in static methods, which are not OO by nature. I believe that Singletons would've made a much better choice.



    Due to all these difficulties, I will settle for the following syntax
    

    ApplicationTestController c = new ApplicationTestController();

    c.index().isOk().is(UTF8).is(HTML);

    My module allows you to have similar syntax to this.

    In this syntax I know exactly which function is called. I don't care which Path is used, and definitely not which method (GET/POST).

    I know which arguments to use with a simple "auto complete". If I change the signature of the controller I can simply refactor my "TestApplicationController" to modify the test easily accordingly.

    Note I am not mentioning Response anywhere.. I have less code, HTML and UTF8 are Enums, so I know exactly what my options are.

    Getting Started

    All the info and tutorials you need can be found by code samples, and wiki pages available to you in GitHub (link below).

    Since this little (10 classes.. ) project of mine combines cool technologies like Play and CGLib, I will write a series of posts about how I wrote it. (links below).


    References

  • Project on GitHub

Thank you for the comment.

Building the dependencies in Maven for Axis2 is painful - is the point of this article.
You could add all 62 dependencies to the POM, but that's a lot of work. You probably need one or two dependencies to get it working.

What I did in the end is to download the axis2 project. You will see 62 jars there.
I manually copied them one by one to the classpath in order to figure out which jar I was missing. Once I had that, I knew which Maven dependency I needed.
